Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: Psychological and Behavioral Preparatory Responses to Male Aggressive Vocal Signaling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Personal aggression has serious consequences yet often starts with seemingly trivial verbal disputes ("I don't like your tone"). These verbal conflicts are common between both acquaintances and strangers. Some of these conflicts quickly end with one party standing down, but others escalate verbally to physical, even fatal, fights. What role do vocal qualities (not what people say, but physical aspects of the voice) play in determining whether a verbal dispute becomes a fight? Research on other animals indicates that vocal qualities often give information about physical strength and aggressive intentions, which can predict fight outcomes and thus affect an individual's motivation to fight. For example, previous research shows that men with lower pitched voices are judged as being more likely to win fistfights than men with less deep voices. In this case, pitch is a way to manipulate "signal intensity", which evolutionary theory suggests would convey important cues useful to a potential attacker. An intense signal conveys the speaker is more motivated to aggress or is physically stronger than would a weaker signal. Theory suggests that the listener's likelihood of retreating or attacking should be affected by perceptions of the voice, but research has not yet tested those hypotheses in humans. Thus this project builds on previous findings about perceiving voices, to extend it to people's preparation to aggress. The investigators use experiments to create mildly competitive situations and examine whether signal speaker's vocal features affects listeners' aggressive inclinations. Understanding how vocal qualities can reduce or increase aggression will help professionals who are regularly exposed to violence (e.g., police officers) to navigate danger, and inform intervention programs that aim at curtailing violence.

This project tests key hypotheses drawn from M. Enquist's retaliation-cost model, a leading model of aggressive communication in animals. The investigators will measure people's psychological and physical responses to vocal features that serve as strong or weak signals to aggressive intent or aggressive ability. In three sets of experiments, the investigators will manipulate whether the signal intensity of a male speaker's voice is strong or weak. Experiment Set 1 also manipulates facial dominance of the speaker, and whether the topic of his expressed anger is of significant or minimal value. Interactions of the three manipulated variables are predicted to affect listener's judgments about aggressive intent. Experiment Set 2 will test how listeners' physical strength and cues of competition for mates influence their attention to and memory of the speaker. Experiment Set 3 extends the Set 2 by focusing on listeners' aggressive thinking and preparation (e.g., immediate increases in physical strength) in response to hearing signals of strong versus weak intensity. To enhance the validity of the project, the investigators will recruit police officers to participate in Experiment Set 1. To facilitate cross-cultural comparisons, the investigators will perform parallel experiments in China, a country with much lower homicide rates than the U.S. This project will provide a deeper understanding of the evolution and function of voice pitch in aggressive interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interpersonal physical aggression is a prevailing social problem. It causes injuries (and sometimes the loss of life) and consumes public resources when aggressors are brought to trial. However, people—especially young adult men—often engage in interpersonal physical aggression despite its costs. Prior research drawing on evolutionary psychological theories suggests that interpersonal physical aggression exists because it facilitates intrasexual competition for fitness-enhancing resources such as food, shelter, and mating opportunities. Compared to young adult women, young adult men are more likely to engage in interpersonal physical aggression because young adult men’s reproductive success depends more heavily on outcompeting their same-sex rivals.

 

Our research extends this line of work by studying aggressive signaling that often occurs at an early stage of interpersonal physical aggression. Indeed, interpersonal physical aggression rarely starts with all-out fights but with rounds of verbal exchange (e.g., “What are you looking at?”, “I don’t like the tone of your voice!”). Drawing on the retaliation-cost model, we hypothesize that these verbal exchanges—despite having random content—serve an important function. That is, they allow aggressors to broadcast and assess each other’s willingness to fight (i.e., aggressive intent).

 

To test our hypothesis, we conducted a series of experiments where we examined male (and female) participants’ perceptions of, cognitive responses to, and behavioral responses to male speakers whose voice pitch was manipulated. Voice pitch describes how high or low a person’s voice is perceived by listeners, has been shown to be involved in aggressive signaling, and can be cleanly manipulated independent of speech content. In particular, human voice pitch is highly flexible and thus suitable to signal states that change situationally, such as one’s aggressive intent. The participants to our experiments included U.S. and Chinese university students, U.S. adults recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk, and active-duty U.S. police officers. In what follows, we describe findings from male participants because interpersonal physical aggression is primarily a “young male syndrome.”

 

In Experiment Set 1, we found that male participants generally perceived male speakers who lowered their voice pitch to address an adversary to be more likely to aggress (i.e., having greater aggressive intent) than male speakers who raised their voice pitch to address an adversary. Importantly, pitch lowering enhanced male speakers’ perceived aggressive intent regardless of the speakers’ manipulated 1) physical strength and 2) apparent social status (e.g., driving a beat-up, second-hand Volvo or a brand new BMW). These findings suggest that men assess their adversaries’ aggressive intent from the adversaries’ pitch modulation and this assessment is made independently of the adversaries’ perceived ability to inflict costs on them (i.e., the perceivers).

 

In Experiment Set 2, we found that, under a mating-motive prime that activated a competitive mindset, heterosexual male participants who were higher in trait aggressiveness or physical strength were generally more accurate in distinguishing between previously-heard and -unheard low- (but not high-) pitched male voices. We replicated this finding with a status-competition prime in a subsequent experiment. In a further experiment, we found that male participants with larger flexed biceps generally paid more attention to a low- (but not high-) pitched male voice when they were made to imagine that they were competing with the male speaker to date a girl they both liked. These findings suggest that men tend to allocate more cognitive resources to low-pitched male voices in competitive contexts. We believe that this strategic allocation of cognitive resources facilitates retaliation against a man who just issued a threat with low-pitched voices.

 

In the last set of experiments, we found that, under a status-competition prime, male participants who were higher in trait aggressiveness generally showed greater behavioral aggression (e.g., sending louder and longer segments of white noises) toward a male speaker with low (but not high) pitched voices. [In the experiments, participants actually sent the white noises to computers instead of any real person.] This finding suggests that low-pitched male voices can provoke physical aggression from aggressive men in a competitive context.

 

Taken together, findings from three sets of experiments drawing on diverse samples of participants confirm our hypothesis that voice pitch—a prominent feature of human vocalization—can function as an aggressive signal in male-male competitive interactions. In terms of intellectual merits, this research enhances social scientists’ understanding of the dynamics of interpersonal physical aggression by studying a previously-overlooked but critical aspect of interpersonal physical aggression, namely aggressive vocal signaling. In terms of broader impact, other professionals can use our findings to design better training materials for self-defense (e.g., calming everybody down when noticing remarks being made with a low-pitched voice) and reducing interpersonal physical aggression (e.g., maintaining one’s voice pitch in arguments to prevent conflicts from escalating).
